evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: President Trump’s purported removal of Plaintiffs from their Commissioner roles violates the CPSA because the removals are not based on neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. The removals are therefore ultra vires, and they exceed the President’s constitutional and statutory authority.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Declare that Defendants’ removal of Plaintiffs from their roles as CPSC Commissioners was unlawful and that Plaintiffs are entitled to continue serving out their terms as CPSC Commissioners;

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Enjoin Defendant Feldman from obstructing Plaintiffs in any way from carrying out their duties as CPSC Commissioners, including by terminating their staff and barring their access to agency resources;

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Enjoin Defendants Bessent, Vought, and Feldman from depriving Plaintiffs of the pay and benefits that Plaintiffs are entitled to receive as CPSC Commissioners, and order Defendants Bessent, Vought, and Feldman to restore all pay and benefits that have been unlawfully withheld from Plaintiffs and their staff;

extracted.value: Injunctive relief against Defendants Bessent, Vought, and Feldman for pay and benefits

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Award Plaintiffs their costs and attorneys’ fees for this action;

evidence.text: Congress provided that they could be “removed by the President” prior to the end of their terms only “for neglect of duty or malfeasance in office but for no other cause.” Id. § 2053(a).

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Article I of the U.S. Constitution vests “[a]ll legislative Powers” in Congress. U.S. Const. art. I, § 1.
